paper_metadata.title: Conditional cash transfers and parenting support program effects on child development outcomes

program_information.program_name: Prospera CCT with Educación Inicial (EI) parenting program
program_information.region: Rural communities in three Mexican states

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: Conditional cash transfer programs (CCTs) have shown mixed effects on child development outcomes in the context of poverty. | The parenting program (EI: Educación Inicial) was implemented at scale among beneficiaries of Prospera (a CCT, previously Oportunidades and Progresa).

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: Here, we use data from a randomized effectiveness trial to examine the pathways connecting parenting support and child development. | Findings were that participation in the T2 arm of the study was associated with a 13% increase in the number of play activities that parents engaged in with their children
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: Communities were stratified by indigenous classification and randomized to one of three arms: (T0) Comparison group (CCT benefits only); (T1) CCT benefits plus availability of EI in the community; or (T2) CCT benefits plus promotion and encouragement by the CCT program to participate in EI.

bonus_information.qualitative_evidence_citation: Qualitative reports suggest that recruitment of caregivers to participate in the EI parenting program was more difficult in the T1 arm when compared with T2

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: The parenting program (EI: Educación Inicial) was implemented at scale among beneficiaries of Prospera (a CCT, previously Oportunidades and Progresa)
evidence_citations.country_citation: Here, we use data from a randomized effectiveness trial to examine the pathways connecting parenting support and child development... from 91 rural communities in three Mexican states
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: Participants included children between the ages of 3 and 5 years old (n = 1,362) from 91 rural communities in three Mexican states
